body.p: Mohammed Aassila

A Heron triangle has integer sides and integer area; such a triangle is always the juxtaposition (in a positive or negative sense) of two pythagorean triangles along a common leg. The common leg may or may not be an integer, as in the triangles 131415(13,14,15)(13,14,15) and 52930(5,29,30)(5,29,30) respectively. There are still several nice open problems concerning Heron triangles. For example, it is not known if there exist Heron triangles having all medians integers, see 1345 for related problems and results.

In this note, we present some results on the existence of pairs of incongruent Heron triangles with the same area and with the same area and perimeter. We furthermore prove the existence of Heron triangles with prescribed inradius and circumradius. Throughout this note we denote by 𝑎𝑏𝑐a,b,ca,b,c the sides of a triangle and 𝑆SS its area. The letters s𝑟s,r\mathrm{s},r and 𝑅RR stand for the semiperimeter, inradius and circumradius respectively.
As a first result we prove the existence of pairs of incongruent Heron triangles with the same area. More precisely
Theorem 1 There are many pairs of incongruent Heron triangles having the same area.

Proof. Let subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛𝑛0(Fn)n≥0(F_{n})_{n\geq 0} be the Fibonacci sequence defined by formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹00subscript𝐹11F0=0,F1=1F_{0}=0,F_{1}=1 and subscript𝐹𝑛2subscript𝐹𝑛1subscript𝐹𝑛Fn+2=Fn+1+FnF_{n+2}=F_{n+1}+F_{n} for all integers 𝑛0n≥0n\geq 0. Then there are many pairs of incongruent Heron triangles having the same area 𝑆⋅subscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛1subscript𝐹𝑛2subscript𝐹𝑛3subscript𝐹𝑛4subscript𝐹𝑛5S=Fn⋅Fn+1⋅Fn+2⋅Fn+3⋅Fn+4⋅Fn+5S=F_{n}\cdot F_{n+1}\cdot F_{n+2}\cdot F_{n+3}\cdot F_{n+4}\cdot F_{n+5}. As a second result in this note we have:
Theorem 2 There are infinitely many pairs of incongruent Heron triangles with the same area and perimeter.
Proof. Let 𝑡1t≥1t\geq 1 be any positive integer and let subscript𝑇1T1T_{1} and subscript𝑇2T2T_{2} be triangles of sides
and
Then, subscript𝑇1T1T_{1} and subscript𝑇2T2T_{2} are incongruent Heron triangles having the same semiperimeter
and the same area
We end this first part of the note by stating the following
Problem. Prove or disprove that for any positive integer 𝑘2k≥2k\geq 2 there exist 𝑘kk mutually incongruent Heron triangles having the same area and semiperimeter.
As a third result, we have:
Theorem 3 Let𝑘1k≥1k\geq 1be a positive integer Then, there exists a Heron triangle𝑇TThaving𝑟𝑘r=k.r=k.
Proof. Let formulae-sequence𝑋𝑠𝑎𝑦𝑠𝑏X=s-a,y=s-bX=s-a,y=s-b and 𝑧𝑠𝑐z=s-cz=s-c. Since 𝑟𝑆𝑠r=S/sr=S/s it suffices to show that the equation
has a positive solution 𝜒𝑦𝑧χ,y,z\chi,y,z. We choose 𝑧1z=1z=1 and equation (2) now becomes

𝑋superscript𝑘2𝑦1𝑦superscript𝑘2X=k2⁢(y+1)y-k2X=\frac{k^{2}(y+1)}{y-k^{2}}. (3)
Clearly, one may choose 𝑦superscript𝑘21y=k2+1y=k^{2}+1 and then by (3) we have 𝑋superscript𝑘42superscript𝑘2X=k4+2⁢k2X=k^{4}+2k^{2}. Hence, the triangle of sides

Finally, the last result of this note is:
Theorem 4. Let𝑝ppbe a prime such that𝑝1p≡1p\equiv 1 (mod 4). Then, there exists a Heron triangle𝑇TThaving𝑅𝑝R=p.R=p.
Proof Since 𝑝pp is a sum of two squares (see Dickson 2), we can write 𝑝superscript𝑢2superscript𝑣2p=u2+v2.p=u^{2}+v^{2}. Then, the triangle of sides
is Heron and has 𝑅superscript𝑢2superscript𝑣2𝑝R=u2+v2=pR=u^{2}+v^{2}=p. Indeed, this follows immediately from the fact that the above triangle is right angled.

Remark. It is clear from Theorem 4 that if 𝑘kk is an arbitrary positive integer which is a multiple of 𝑝pp, then there exists a Heron triangle of circumradius 𝑅𝑘R=kR=k. To see this, it suffices to consider the triangle which is similar to the triangle given by (4) but whose sides are 𝑘𝑝k/pk/p times longer.
Since almost every integer is divisible by a prime 𝑝1p≡1p\equiv 1 (mod 4), the result of Theorem 4 is “almost” true in general, however we claim that:
Conjecture. Let 𝑝pp be a prime such that 𝑝11𝑚𝑜𝑑12p≡11⁢(m⁢o⁢d⁢12)p\equiv 11(mod12) . Then, there is no Heron triangle having 𝑅𝑝R=p.R=p.
